contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Jaguar warrior.jpg|thumb|Aztec jaguar warrior]] '''Jaguar warriors''' or '''jaguar knights''', ''ocēlōtl'' {{IPA-nah|o'seːloːt͡ɬ||}} (singular)<ref name="dic" /> or ''ocēlōmeh'' {{IPA-nah|oseː'loːmeʔ||ocelomeh.ogg}} ([[plural]])<ref name="dic">''Nahuatl Dictionary.'' (1997). Wired Humanities Project. University of Oregon. Retrieved September 5, 2012, from [http://whp.uoregon.edu/dictionaries/nahuatl/index.lasso link]</ref> were members of the [[Aztec warfare|Aztec military]].<ref name="colonial-mexico.com">[http://www.colonial-mexico.com/Central%20Mexico/ixm.html Jaguar Warriors. Ixmiquilpan. Mexico murals<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> They were a type of Aztec warrior called a ''cuāuhocēlōtl'' {{IPA-nah|kʷaːwo'seːloːt͡ɬ||}}.<ref name="Sanchez" /> The word ''cuāuhocēlōtl'' derives from the [[eagle warrior]] ''cuāuhtli'' {{IPA-nah|'kʷaːwt͡ɬi||}} and the Jaguar Warrior ''ocēlōtl'' .<ref name="Sanchez" >Sánchez-Murillo, R. (2012). La palabra universal. ''Ricardo Sánchez-Murillo.'' Retrieved September 5, 2012, from [http://ricardosm.com/2012/03/21/la-palabra-del-universo/ link].</ref> They were an elite military unit similar to the [[eagle warrior]]s. The jaguar motif was used due to the belief that the [[jaguar]] represented [[Tezcatlipoca]], god of the night sky. Aztecs also wore these dresses at war because they believed the animal's strengths would be given to them during battles.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Jaguar warriors were used at the battlefront in military campaigns. They were also used to capture prisoners for sacrifice to the Aztec gods.<ref name="colonial-mexico.com"/> Many [[statue]]s and images (in [[pre-Columbian]] and [[post-Columbian]] [[codex|codices]]) of these warriors have survived.<ref>[http://www.odysseyphoto.com/portfolio/PreHispanic/Precolumbian.html Pre-Columbian Stock Photography, Pre-Hispanic Stock Photos, Mesoamerican Travel Photos<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> They fought with a wooden sword studded with [[Obsidian use in Mesoamerica|obsidian]] volcanic glass blades, called a [[macuahuitl]]. They also used spears and [[atlatl]]s. They believed their feathered shield had magic powers. To become a jaguar warrior, a member of the Aztec army had to capture twelve enemies during two consecutive battles. This was said to honor their gods in a way far greater than killing enemy soldiers in the battlefield. For a warrior to kill an enemy was considered clumsy. ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[Aztec warfare]] *[[Jaguars in Mesoamerican culture]] *[[Eagle_warrior|Eagle Warrior]] [[Category:Aztec warfare]] [[Category:Military units and formations of the Middle Ages]] {{mesoamerica-stub}}
